title-group.article-title: Assessment of Knee Implant Alignment Using Coordinate Measurement on Three-Dimensional Computed Tomography Reconstructions

article-meta.aff: 1Orthopedic Department, University of Basel, Spitalstrasse, Basel, Switzerland
2Anatomical Institute, University of Basel, Pestalozzistrasse, Basel, Switzerland

author-notes.corresp: Andrej M. Nowakowski, Orthopedic Department, University of Basel, Spitalstrasse 21, 4031 Basel, Switzerland Email: andrej.nowakowski@unibas.ch

abstract.p: The rapid development of navigation systems designed to improve implant alignment calls for precise methods to verify positioning. One new approach to assess knee implant alignment is coordinate measurement (CM) using reference objects on 3-dimensional reconstructions of computed tomographic (CT) image sequences. The objectives of this study were to determine whether implant alignment can be accurately and precisely examined with CT-based CM, and whether correct positioning of a transversal support implant can be attained using a specially developed aiming instrument. Average deviation of CT measurements from those made with a digital caliper remained within the caliper’s range of error. This level of accuracy was observer independent. CT-based CM can be used for accurate and precise alignment verification. As well, precise alignment of transversal support can be achieved during implantation with a conventional aiming device, assuming the bony landmarks are appropriately recognized.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Artificial knee replacement with endoprosthesis has been an established technique now for several decades. In the coming decades, the number of knee replacement surgeries will increase rapidly.1,2 Various studies have found that navigation-based implantation can reduce malalignment during total knee arthroplasty (TKA), and thus one can expect better results.3-9

The rapid developments occurring in this field call for precise methods to evaluate implant position. Choi et al10 found that plain radiographs fail to reflect alignment of a total knee prosthesis. Thus, 3-dimensional (3D) imaging procedures are required for good measurements. Specialized software programs allowing surface and angular measurements on 3D reconstructions generated from computed tomographic (CT) or magnetic resonance images are now available.11

One new approach is the use of coordinate measurement (CM) with reference objects (eg, circle, plane, sphere, cylinder, cone) on 3D reconstructions from CT image sequences to evaluate knee implant alignment, using image visualization software (VGStudio Max 2.1.1, Volume Graphics GmbH, Heidelberg, Germany). To date, studies have implemented older software versions without the CM application, for example, the study by Günther et al12 on 3D visualization and surgical planning for abdominal tumors in children using VGStudio Max 1.1, or that of Wong et al13 on the 3D depiction of dentinal carious lesions using VGStudio Max 1.0.

Using the CT-based CM application, this study evaluated implant alignment after insertion of a modular component of the new knee prosthesis concept, the transversal support tibial plateau (TSTP). The TSTP implant consists of 2 individual joint surfaces (JS), reinforced beneath the joint line by joint surface supports (JSS) and buttressed by a single transversal support (TS)14,15 (Figure 1).

caption.p: The transversal support tibial plateau consists of 2 joint surfaces (JS) reinforced beneath the joint line by 2 joint surface supports (JSS) and buttressed by a single transversal support (TS)15
Source: Reprinted by courtesy of the Medical Literary Publication Society (Medizinisch Literarische Verlagsgesellschaft mbH), Uelzen, Germany.

sec.p: This configuration should provide good bony fixation, especially for the TS, and ensure long-term alignment of the individual JSs. Because this is a new treatment concept in the field of tibial plateau fixation, however, no evidence regarding insertion techniques is currently available.16

One possible implantation technique is the use of an aiming device that can be attached at the articular midpoint, with drill guides to align the TS. Typically, tibial plateau alignment is defined with the first saw cut, which is carried out using an oscillating saw on a cut-block aligned with bony landmarks. Use of this new implantation technique enables one to define tibial plateau alignment through drilling with the help of an aiming device.

The primary objective of this study was to determine whether implant alignment can be accurately and precisely evaluated using the CM. The secondary objective was to evaluate whether the use of a specially designed aiming device can attain correct alignment of the TS implant.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: After approval by the Ethics Committee of Basel (EKBB), Switzerland, 12 (6 pairs left and right) formalin-fixed human cadaveric proximal tibias, which had been prepared in an anatomy course, were used. Average age was 84 ± 11 years. Six specimens were male and 6 female.

An aiming device (Figure 2) was specially designed to achieve correct alignment of the TS (Aesculap, Tuttlingen, Germany) implant. Using this device, TS insertion was evaluated at defined intervals of 15, 25, and 35 mm beneath the joint line from both medial and lateral approaches.

caption.p: Specially developed aiming device for transversal support (TS) implantation from both medial and lateral approaches in defined intervals of 15, 25, and 35 mm

The aiming device is composed of a base plate, adjusting aids (aa) in various directions and axes, as well as 2 styli to grip the midpoints of each joint surface. Drilling proceeds with calibration of the drill sleeve using the bracket on the aiming arm. The drill diameter is 12.0 or 12.1 mm, and drilling is performed at defined intervals to the joint line. Supplementary drilling using an extra drill sleeve with 3.2 mm is optional for k-wire placement.16
Source: Reprinted by courtesy of John Wiley & Sons Inc.

sec.p: Drilling to align the TS was carried out as described in a previous study detailing the surgical approach for the TSTP.16 The base plate of the aiming device is fixed distal to the tibial tuberosity with crossed k-wires. By adjusting various settings, the styli can be precisely aligned to the midpoints of the joint surfaces medially and laterally, with consideration for the individual joint surface slopes.

In certain cases where the joint surface midpoints deviated only a few millimeters from the fixed position distance between the styli, this distance was split equally between the 2 toward the transversal plane.

Using the method of Hertel and Lehmann,17 the joint surface midpoint is determined as the intersection between the maximal sagittal length and the maximal transverse extension. As Fick18 described many years ago, there is mild offset of the 2 separate, oval joint surfaces:
The longitudinal diameters of the two separate joint surfaces are not perpendicular to the largest cross-sectional diameter of the proximal tibial joint surface. However, were one to position the oval joint surfaces exactly sagittally, this would yield the corresponding offset of the joint surfaces to each other in the sagittal direction.
To compensate for this, the maximal transverse diameter of the proximal tibial joint surface was used instead of the respective maximal transverse diameters of each compartment.

After adjustment and attachment of the aiming device, a k-wire (diameter = 3.2 mm) was drilled using the corresponding drill sleeve until entering the opposing cortex. The second drilling proceeded over this guide wire with a definitive drill (diameter = 12.0 mm for the aluminum implants, diameter = 12.1 mm for the polyamide implants) until reaching the opposing cortex. The aiming device was removed, and both articular midpoints (as identified by the styli of the aiming device) were marked with lead pellets (diameter = 2 mm), which were then affixed with fast cement (Cementit CA 12, Merz + Bentli AG, Niederwangen, Switzerland; Figure 3).

caption.p: Marking of the mid-articular points with affixed lead pellets (diameter = 2 mm): View from proximal onto the joint surfaces of a left tibia after 3-dimensional reconstruction using a computed tomographic image sequence

sec.p: After the drilling length was determined with a digital caliper, individually adjusted TS implants were inserted (half received aluminum, diameter = 12.0 mm implants and half received polyamide PA-66, diameter = 12.1 mm implants) and then fixed using a polyurethane resin (Neukadur MultiCast 2, Altropol Kunststoff GmbH, Stockelsdorf, Germany).

Specimens were scanned using a GE Lightspeed 16 X-ray CT scanner (General Electric Healthcare Corporation, Waukesha, WI): 120 kV, slice thickness 0.625 mm, voxel depth 0.5 mm, voxel height 0.296875 mm, voxel width 0.296875 mm.

The DICOM images in bone kernel were imported to on-display measurement using the image visualization software (VGStudio Max 2.1.1, Volume Graphics GmbH, Heidelberg, Germany). Coordinate measurement (CM) is an optional add-on module using different types of reference objects (eg, circle, plane, sphere, cylinder, cone). There are different fit methods available. We used a best-fit algorithm based on a set of given fit points on the calibration surface in combination with a least squares (Gaussian fit) method.
An initial raycasting-based 3D volume rendering of the proximal tibias was performed from the DICOM images.

To orient the specimen within a defined coordinate system in 3D space, we used a 3–2–1 registration. For the first step, the tilt of the object toward the z-axis was determined using 3 coordinate points. Next, 2 coordinate points were required to establish the rotation around the z-axis and the position of the y-axis. Finally, one coordinate point defined the origin along the x-axis. This routine was simplified using a software-integrated algorithm, so that the alignment could be exactly determined using three control geometries (plane, line, and point). The specified coordinate points were as follows:

list-item.p: the centers of both spheres attached to the lead pellets, and
the center of an inner circle fitted to the implant insertion site (medial or lateral, corresponding to the side of the approach, Figure 4A).

caption.p: A, Three-dimensional depiction of the coronal plane as the clipping plane, defined by attaching spheres to both lead pellets and a fitted inner circle at the insertion point of the implant (medial or lateral, corresponding to implantation side). B, Definition of the coordinate system, corresponding to the perpendicular axes, there is a transversal plane and a sagittal plane

sec.p: A coordinate system with corresponding perpendicular axes was configured based on these coordinate points (Figure 4B).
The CT image sequences could be reconstructed in 2-dimensions and oriented within the coordinate system.
The following measurement protocol was performed during CM by all 3 authors to account for interobserver variability:

list-item.p: surface determination to the bone/implant interface,
measurement of implant diameter using a reference cylinder to calculate the best fit based on a set of given fit points (Figure 5), and
measurement of implant length using a distance caliper with a snap function that positioned the measuring instrument’s handles automatically on the material boundaries.

caption.p: Screenshot of the user interface of the VGStudio MAX software during the best fit procedure

Fit points (red) can be placed in both the 2-dimensional (2D) depiction (transversal plane a, sagittal plane b, coronal plane c), as well as the 3D image (d). An optional preview of the adapted geometrical element (here the yellow cylinder) can be seen, if the touch point is selected.

sec.p: The auto fit point option dramatically increases the number of fit points. Based on these fit points, the reference object can then be calculated (Figure 6).

caption.p: Histogram of the fit points for the reference cylinder from Figure 5

Based on the fit points defined by the user, an initial, preliminary reference object is produced. The auto fit point option then uses this preliminary reference object to generate a new set of fit points that are distributed over the surface of the preliminary reference object and then projected onto the surface of the voxel data. The reference object is then generated. During this process, the number of fit points is drastically increased, in this example to approximately 1000.

sec.p: To verify whether correct alignment of the TS was attainable using the aiming device, deviation in the respective axes was evaluated as follows.

Deviation in rotational alignment was assessed by examining the transversal plane. This was accomplished by superimposing the plane through the center of the lead pellet spheres over that through the center of the reference cylinder. In this way, deviation was determined from simple measurements between the cylinder axis and the centers of the lead pellet spheres. (Figure 7). Varus/valgus deviation was measured in a similar manner in the coronal plane.

caption.p: A, Depiction of the central axis (solid line) of the previously determined reference cylinder in the corresponding transversal plane through the implant: The reference spheres (dotted line) of the lead pellets are projected orthogonal onto the selected layer. In this example, the implantation occurred from a medial approach, so that deviation is greater laterally. B, Enlargement of the situation in (A) for the closer observation of the deviation of implant alignment in this region

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The lead pellets caused artifacts on CT imaging as expected in the region of the tibial tuberosity, where measurements were no longer relevant. In contrast, the CT data in the region of the aluminum and PA-66 implants remained practically free of artifact.

With further analysis, the use of CT-based CM showed only minimal deviations from the actual implant sizes. As a demonstrative overview of these results, the respective measures of implant diameter (∅) and length (L) are presented in Table 1. Deviation of the CT measurements from those attained by the digital caliper remained primarily within the realm of caliper error (±0.1 mm). Thus, the distribution of diameter measurements was smaller using the reference cylinder and auto fit point option than that of the 2-point length measurement using the distance caliper with snap function (Figure 8).

caption.p: Determination of Implant Size Diameter (∅) and Length (L) in Millimeters (mm) Using Coordinate Measurement Performed by 3 Different Observers
Deviation of computed tomographic (CT) measurements compared to those of a digital caliper, performed by 3 examiners

The distribution of the diameter measurement values (round marker, blue) using the reference cylinder and auto fit point option appears smaller than that of the 2-point length determination values (triangular marker, red) using a distance caliper with a snap option.

sec.p: Mean deviation for implant diameter measurement was 0.02 mm (SD 0.05) for examiner 1, 0.00 mm (SD 0.02) for examiner 2, and 0.02 mm (SD 0.03) for examiner 3. The calculated deviation regarding implant position was only minimally greater, with 0.03 mm (SD 0.09) for examiner 1, 0.02 mm (SD 0.11) for examiner 2, and 0.03 mm (SD 0.11) for examiner 3. Because of this minimal deviation, further statistical analysis on interobserver variability was forgone.

Transversal support alignment measures to verify the accuracy of the specialized aiming device identified malalignment up to 1.6° (internal rotation specimen 12, varus angulation specimen 10, Table 2). The mean internal rotation was 0.11° (SD 0.89°) and the mean valgus angulation was 0.13° (SD 0.63°). Here as well, considering the minimal deviation, further statistical analysis, for example, regarding the extent of interval-dependent deviation, was forgone.

caption.p: Implant Deviation: Internal Rotation (ϕrot) and Valgus Angulation (ϕvar)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The use of conventional CM machines, for example, in the area of abrasion measurements after total knee arthroplasty, is well established.19 Currently, in the industrial sector as well, CT-based CM systems are increasingly applied for nondestructive testing and evaluation. Generally, the 3D accuracy of CT systems is influenced by varying underlying physical processes such as scatter, beam hardening, off-focal radiation, detector point spread function, and partial volume effects.20

Various methods have been developed for standardization and optimization of 3D CT measurements, for example, matrix transformation in the 3D coordinate system21 or use of a parametric boundary reconstruction algorithm.20

With CT, a point density is generated that is not attained by other measurement technologies. Compared with conventional CM machines, the CT-based CM individual minimum and maximum measurements are smaller and larger, respectively. This occurrence is used, for example, by the currently used software (VGStudio Max 2.1), for the surface determination or the fitting reference object measurement. The surface determination has considerable impact on measurement accuracy. Because of the varying materials (air, bone, aluminum, or PA-66) present, we did not perform the software-integrated automatic surface determination, but instead an expanded surface determination. This expanded surface determination allowed varying interpretations of the same gray values, dependent on the voxels in the region.

This step, interpreting equal gray values in the histogram to define the material–bony interface with partial volume effect, could also have led to large interobserver variability. However, the respective measures by individual examiners, particularly those for diameter based on the reference cylinder, remained within the error range of the control values (±0.1 mm measured by digital caliper). Here the least squares fit method also contributed, because again the deviation was less than that with the 2-point length measurement using the caliper with snap option. With the least squares fit method, the sum of deviations of the fit points from the reference object were minimized. Generally, for a large number of points, as shown in this study with the auto fit point option, there is a Gaussian distribution curve. The geometrical element (eg, the reference cylinder) is then positioned by the software so that the sum of negative deviations equals the sum of positive deviations. The use of CM on the 3D reconstructions with reference objects can thus reach a high level of precision.

In summary, the CT-based CM allows very good accuracy and precision for the verification of implant alignment. Further tests of accuracy could be added, for example, common reference objects could be scanned simultaneously with the subjects and the data compiled together. With automatization of the surface determination using this reference object, the possibility for interobserver variability would be further diminished.

Regarding the aiming device, the maximum individual alignment deviation of the TS measured 1.6° for both implant rotation around the axial axis and for varus/valgus angulation. Thus, even the extreme values are well within the normal range of 3° deviation, which is generally indicated as a desired goal for the mechanical leg axis.5,10,22,23

Originally, we planned further analysis of whether the range of options (15, 25, and 35 mm beneath the joint line) or the side of implantation (medial or lateral) influenced implant alignment, for example, effects of the more oblique drill angle based on proximal tibial anatomy or increasing cortical thickness toward distal. However, the overall good results with minimal deviation considering the specimen number and additional factors, such as the possible variability from lead pellet attachment alone, convinced us that such statements would be meaningless.

Limitations of this study regarding verification of the aiming device are, of course, that the attachment points were marked, and there was no direct examination of the relationships to the bony landmarks themselves. Use of lead spheres is not possible in real-life cases. These methods were selected for use under laboratory conditions, to check the system-inherent precision independent of the choice of bony landmarks.

Our procedure was chosen specifically because, for one, the discernment of bony landmarks, even on CT, is already susceptible to intra- and interobserver variability.24 In addition, even with the use of navigation systems for TKA, the primary axes are frequently only selectively incorporated, for example, the epicondylar axis of the distal femur. It is unclear why this measured axis can be more exactly determined using navigation-based techniques rather than a conventionally constructed instrumentation system.

In contrast, modern navigation systems are even able to calculate the center of the femoral head, which is quite difficult to accomplish intraoperatively, apart from visualizing the corresponding alignment in all desired planes on the monitor. These points can be considered particular advantages for the use of navigation in TKA. Undoubtedly the greatest disadvantages are the effort and the additional invasiveness required.

It is not yet clear why certain studies show better limb alignment after navigation TKA3-9 whereas others show no differences compared to conventional TKA.25-30 This could be because of the use of plain radiographs, which fail to reflect the alignment, as verification of position.10 In our opinion, another reason could be that modern navigation systems are more highly developed than the instruments that have been previously studied, and achieve better results. Furthermore, there is the issue of preoperative planning. In conventional TKA, thorough preoperative planning is both necessary and beneficial to attaining optimal results. It is possible that the use of navigation for TKA in some way precludes the meticulousness of this process, shifting normal preoperative planning into the operating room. This might also affect operative duration.

Currently, many manufacturers offer magnetic resonance imaging or CT-based individual, patient-specific cut-blocks to improve intraoperative TKA alignment. CM could become a useful and important tool in this regard and also in the planning and postoperative analysis for controlled studies. For example, preoperative and postoperative CT data sets could be custom matched so that for corresponding data sets the same bony landmarks could be used as reference points. This holds for further follow-up evaluations as well, in which precise determination of potential changes in implant position (eg, from subsidence) could be possible.

In addition, we imagine the implementation of computer-aided design data directly with patient-specific CT data, which would enable exciting new possibilities regarding anatomically oriented implant design development.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Computed tomography–based CM can be used for accurate and precise verification of implant alignment. In addition, CM would be suitable to collect general morphometric data, for operative planning, or to assist with implant design and development.
In addition, conventional aiming devices without the use of modern navigation systems can also attain correct alignment, assuming that the bony landmarks are appropriately recognized.

ack.p: The authors would like to acknowledge the collaborators of Aesculap AG, Research and Development, Tuttlingen, Germany: Mr Roland Böttiger and Dr.-Ing. Thomas M. Grupp for the development and production of the aiming device.
